results.title: Asking Around
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.brief_description: Shaun Tan (author and co-director)describes some of his original concepts for the book of ‘The Lost Thing’ and how these were translated and changed for the film adaptation. Other interviewees Tom Bryant (3D artist)and Leo Baker (animator)discuss points of similarity and difference between the book and film.

results.title: London 1942
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Peter Tanner, Ralph Keene, Greenpark Productions and Verity Films
results.brief_description: A Picture of Wartime London: “A picture of London in 1942 showing a cheerful though bomb-scarred city. The streets are full of British and Allied servicemen. In the parks there are allotments; tomatoes grow on roof tops. The film shows Londoners in the Home Guard and Civil Defence. It ends with scenes of London after dark.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1942-1943)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Annakin, Peter Tanner, Ralph Keene, Greenpark Productions and Verity Films

results.title: Island people
results.creator_credit: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)
results.brief_description:
How Six People Spend Saturday: “It is Saturday in Britain, the day divided between work and rest. In the morning six people, representative of various types, are seen at work in the industrial areas, on the farms and in the cities. They are a craftsman from the Midlands, a typist in a big Manchester office, a tug captain on the River Thames, a farmer from the Lowlands of Scotland, a woman doctor from Cardiff and a small boy who lives in a suburb.
At midday the people crowd out of offices, factories and schools, all going home to prepare for the half-holiday.
Saturday afternoon is set aside for enjoyment. Out they go to their games and amusements, to play football and hockey, rugby and running, to work in the garden, to walk in the woods. At the end of the afternoon they go out to various places of amusement, or they return home to read and play or to make clothes or model aeroplanes.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1940)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Leacock, John Taylor and Realist Film Unit (Great Britain)

results.title: Royal road

results.brief_description: A war-time newsreel study of King and Queen of England [George VI] carrying out their duties as sovereigns, visiting the blitzed areas of England during World War II.

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Donald Carter, Darrel Catling, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: The People's land
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films
results.brief_description: In Britain the National Trust has acqired a number of estates and areas of land of historical interest: they include ancient castles, such as the 14th century Bodian castle, a Chiltern village, the famous valley of Dovedale, a number of prehistoric stone circles, 14,000 acres of Westmorland countryside and an extensive area of downland in Sussex. These estates and landmarks are held in public trust forever.

results.title: The Man on the beat
results.creator_credit: Roger MacDougall, Patricia Murray, Ralph Kemplen and Merlin Films
results.brief_description: The duties and training of a London policeman, known over the world for his courtesy. The London policeman is unarmed, and his duties vary from finding lost children to directing traffic. Dealing with crime is only an occasional part of the ordinary London policeman’s job.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger MacDougall, Patricia Murray, Ralph Kemplen and Merlin Films

results.title: Queen cotton
results.creator_credit: Cecil Musk, C Beaumont and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Looks at the cotton industry in Lancashire which, in the middle of this century, supplied most of the world with cotton goods. Features cranes on the docks in Manchester unloading cotton from all over the world to supply the looms of Lancashire. Includes a fashion shows highlighting cotton fabrics used by well-known British designers. Photographed by Jimmy Rogers, music by William Alwyn and editing by C. Beaumont.

results.title: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion

results.brief_description:
This panel discussion explores the collaborative process between film director and costume designer, the link between costume and character and how costumes connect audiences with on-screen worlds. It also focuses on the artistic role of costuming in the filmmaking process.

Hear from leaders in costuming, film and fashion, the influential Australian film and television costumers Edie Kurzer (‘South Solitary’, ‘Look Both Ways’, ‘Matching Jack’) Cappi Ireland (‘I Frankenstein’, ‘Animal Kingdom’, ‘The Slap’) and Anna Borghesi (‘Mao’s Last Dancer’, ‘Ned Kelly’ ,’Romper Stomper’) in a discussion chaired by NIDA’s Head of Costume, Fiona Reilly.
